abstract:
2. A 300-word version

Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Fenestrated and Branched Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (F/B-EVAR) for Thoracoabdominal Aortic Aneurysm

Background: Fenestrated and branched endovascular aneurysm repair (F/B-EVAR) offers a less invasive alternative to conventional open surgery for thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm (TAAA) and complex abdominal aortic aneurysm. This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of F/B-EVAR.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at multiple centers in the USA, Europe, and Japan. Participants were patients with TAAA or complex AAA eligible for F/B-EVAR. The intervention group received F/B-EVAR, while the control group underwent conventional open surgery. The primary outcome was the incidence of spinal cord injury (SCI) within 30 days post-procedure. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible for patients or clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the F/B-EVAR group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021. Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with 98 participants in the F/B-EVAR group and 97 in the control group analysed. The incidence of SCI was 5% in the F/B-EVAR group and 15% in the control group (p = 0.01). The mean difference in SCI incidence was 10% (95% CI 3% to 17%). Adverse events occurred in 10% of the F/B-EVAR group and 20% of the control group, with no severe events reported.

Trial registration: NCT12345678

Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
